tool.name: ReportPossibleErrors
tool.summary: This GP tool prints a summary of selected items in the Workflow Manager database that may be errors. (For example, users who are not members of any groups.) No corrective action is taken; the errors are merely summarized in the tool's output messages.
tool.usage:
• The default Workflow Manager database must be set before running this tool.

  • The user running this tool must have administrative access to the Workflow Manager database.

param.name: in_mvString_checklist
param.displayname: List of potential problems for which to check
param.dialogReference:
Determines the checks that will be run against the database. The values must be chosen from the following list:

  • DIFFERING_STEP_NAMES - After a step has been added to a workflow, Workflow Manager allows you to customize the name/label of that step as it appears in the workflow. This check flags this condition as an error.

  • GROUPS_WITHOUT_EMAILS - Flags any groups that do not have an associated e-mail address.

  • GROUPS_WITHOUT_PRIVILEGES - Flags any groups that do not have any Workflow Manager privileges associated with them.

  • GROUPS_WITHOUT_USERS - Flags any groups that have no users assigned to them.

  • INVALID_JOB_ASSIGNMENTS - Flags any existing jobs that appear to have been assigned to a non-existent group or user.

  • INVALID_JOB_TYPE_ASSIGNMENTS - Flags any job types with a default assignment that appears to involve a non-existent group or user.

  • INVALID_STEP_ASSIGNMENTS - Flags any workflow steps with a default assignment that appears to involve a non-existent group or user.

  • IS_SELF_PARENT - Flags any jobs that are marked as being their own parent job.

  • JOBS_WITHOUT_TYPES - Certain custom applications have been known to create jobs that have no associated job type. This check attempts to check for existing jobs that don't have any associated job type.

  • JOB_TYPES_WITHOUT_WORKFLOWS - Flags any job types that do not have an associated workflow.

  • MISSING_AOI_MXDS - Flags any job types that do not have an AOI MXD associated with them.

  • MISSING_BASE_MXDS - Flags any job types that do not have a basemap MXD associated with them.

  • NON_ACTIVE_JOB_TYPES - Flags any job types that are not in an "Active" state. (Currently, this encompasses job types in a "Draft" or "Retired" state.)

  • UNASSIGNED_STEPS - Flags any workflow steps that are not assigned to a user or group.

  • USERS_WITHOUT_EMAILS - Flags any users who do not have an e-mail address associated with them.

  • USERS_WITHOUT_GROUPS - Flags any users who are not assigned to at least one group.

  • ZERO_PCT_STEPS - Flags any workflow steps that do not appear to have had their "post-completion percentage" set (that is, this value is still set to "0").

Any combination of the above values may be used.
param.pythonReference:
Determines the checks that will be run against the database. The values must be chosen from the following list:

  • DIFFERING_STEP_NAMES - After a step has been added to a workflow, Workflow Manager allows you to customize the name/label of that step as it appears in the workflow. This check flags this condition as an error.

  • GROUPS_WITHOUT_EMAILS - Flags any groups that do not have an associated e-mail address.

  • GROUPS_WITHOUT_PRIVILEGES - Flags any groups that do not have any Workflow Manager privileges associated with them.

  • GROUPS_WITHOUT_USERS - Flags any groups that have no users assigned to them.

  • INVALID_JOB_ASSIGNMENTS - Flags any existing jobs that appear to have been assigned to a non-existent group or user.

  • INVALID_JOB_TYPE_ASSIGNMENTS - Flags any job types with a default assignment that appears to involve a non-existent group or user.

  • INVALID_STEP_ASSIGNMENTS - Flags any workflow steps with a default assignment that appears to involve a non-existent group or user.

  • IS_SELF_PARENT - Flags any jobs that are marked as being their own parent job.

  • JOBS_WITHOUT_TYPES - Certain custom applications have been known to create jobs that have no associated job type. This check attempts to check for existing jobs that don't have any associated job type.

  • JOB_TYPES_WITHOUT_WORKFLOWS - Flags any job types that do not have an associated workflow.

  • MISSING_AOI_MXDS - Flags any job types that do not have an AOI MXD associated with them.

  • MISSING_BASE_MXDS - Flags any job types that do not have a basemap MXD associated with them.

  • NON_ACTIVE_JOB_TYPES - Flags any job types that are not in an "Active" state. (Currently, this encompasses job types in a "Draft" or "Retired" state.)

  • UNASSIGNED_STEPS - Flags any workflow steps that are not assigned to a user or group.

  • USERS_WITHOUT_EMAILS - Flags any users who do not have an e-mail address associated with them.

  • USERS_WITHOUT_GROUPS - Flags any users who are not assigned to at least one group.

  • ZERO_PCT_STEPS - Flags any workflow steps that do not appear to have had their "post-completion percentage" set (that is, this value is still set to "0").

Any combination of the above values may be used.

param.name: out_file_logFilePath
param.displayname: Location of a text file to which problem descriptions will be written
param.dialogReference: If you specify a file, a list of the problems found will be saved to this file in a simple text format. The file extension should be ".txt".
param.pythonReference: If you specify a file, a list of the problems found will be saved to this file in a simple text format. The file extension should be ".txt".

param.name: in_string_wmxDatabaseAlias
param.dialogReference: An optional parameter specifying that this tool should run on some database other than the default Workflow Manager database. If left blank, the default Workflow Manager database will be used.
param.pythonReference: An optional parameter specifying that this tool should run on some database other than the default Workflow Manager database. If left blank, the default Workflow Manager database will be used.

dataIdInfo.idAbs: This GP tool prints a summary of selected items in the Workflow Manager database that may be errors. (For example, users who are not members of any groups.) No corrective action is taken; the errors are merely summarized in the tool's output messages.
